ai-mn13:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn13:2.1_0: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-mn13:2.3_0: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
ai-mn13:2.4_0: Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?”
ai-mn13:2.5_0: Then those mendicants went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:2.5_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with those wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:2.6_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-mn13:3.1_0: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we.
ai-mn13:3.2_0: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sights, and so do we.
ai-mn13:3.3_0: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we.
ai-mn13:3.4_0: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s disciplinary issues?
ai-mn13:3.5_0: that is to say, teaching, or the instruction to teach the Dhamma.”
ai-mn13:4.1_0: Those mendicants neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:4.2_0: They got up from their seat, thinking:
ai-mn13:4.3_0: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
ai-mn13:5.1_0: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha,
ai-mn13:5.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn13:5.2_0: “Here, reverend Sir, having dressed in the morning time, after picking up our bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-mn13:5.3_0: Then, reverend Sir, occurred to us:
ai-mn13:5.4_0: ‘It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
ai-mn13:5.5_0: Why don’t we go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?’
ai-mn13:5.6_0: Then we went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:5.6_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:5.7_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn13:5.8_0: ‘Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we.
ai-mn13:5.9_0: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sights, and so do we.
ai-mn13:5.10_0: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we.
ai-mn13:5.11_0: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?’
ai-mn13:5.12_0: we neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.
ai-mn13:5.13_0: got up from his seat, thinking:
ai-mn13:5.14_0: ‘We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.’”
ai-mn13:6.1_0: “Mendicants, when wanderers who follow other paths say this, you should say to them:
ai-mn13:6.2_0: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sensual pleasures?
ai-mn13:6.3_0: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sights?
ai-mn13:6.4_0: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to feelings?’
ai-mn13:6.5_0: Questioned like this, the wanderers who follow other paths would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.
ai-mn13:6.7_0: Because they’re out of their dispensation.
ai-mn13:6.8_0: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to this riddle except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.
ai-mn13:7.1_0: And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures?
ai-mn13:7.2_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn13:7.4_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn13:7.8_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn13:7.9_0: these, monks, are the five strands of sense pleasure.
ai-mn13:7.10_0: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:8.1_0: And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures?
ai-mn13:8.2_0: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as
ai-mn13:8.3_0: computing, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
ai-mn13:8.4_0: But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst.
ai-mn13:8.5_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:9.1_0: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to earn any money.
ai-mn13:9.2_0: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-mn13:9.3_0: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’
ai-mn13:9.4_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:10.1_0: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money.
ai-mn13:10.2_0: And so they experience pain and sadness because of their wealth.
ai-mn13:10.3_0: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
ai-mn13:10.4_0: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.
ai-mn13:10.5_0: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
ai-mn13:10.6_0: ‘What used to be mine is gone.’
ai-mn13:10.7_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:11.1_0: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
ai-mn13:11.2_0: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and fighting, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
ai-mn13:11.3_0: resulting in death and deadly pain.
ai-mn13:11.4_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:12.1_0: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
ai-mn13:12.2_0: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
ai-mn13:12.3_0: resulting in death and deadly pain.
ai-mn13:12.4_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:13.1_0: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
ai-mn13:13.2_0: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
ai-mn13:13.3_0: resulting in death and deadly pain.
ai-mn13:13.4_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:14.1_0: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they take care of sensual pleasures, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.
ai-mn13:14.2_0: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—
ai-mn13:14.3_1: cutting off hands or feet, the foot would cut off.
ai-mn13:14.3_2: They made a horn blazing change, and wrapped in the hands. They plant the hands, wretch it, or lamps or a creeper; and they make the mouthfuls even a scalpel, or even though it’s braid.
ai-mn13:14.4_0: resulting in death and deadly pain.
ai-mn13:14.5_0: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:15.1_0: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-mn13:15.2_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-mn13:15.3_0: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:16.1_0: And what is the escape from sensual pleasures?
ai-mn13:16.2_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sensual pleasures: this is the escape from sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:17.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:17.2_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
ai-mn13:18.1_0: And what is the gratification of sights?
ai-mn13:18.2_0: Suppose there was a girl of the brahmins, aristocrats, or householders in her fifteenth or sixteenth year, neither too tall nor too short, neither too thin nor too fat, neither too dark nor too fair. Is she not at the height of her beauty and prettiness?”
ai-mn13:18.4_0: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from this beauty and prettiness
ai-mn13:19.1_0: And what is the drawback of sights?
ai-mn13:19.2_0: Suppose that some time later you were to see that same sister—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy.
ai-mn13:19.4_0: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
ai-mn13:19.6_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:20.1_0: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.
ai-mn13:20.3_0: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
ai-mn13:20.5_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:21.1_0: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn13:21.2_0: I am dead for one day, or dead for two days, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn13:21.4_0: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
ai-mn13:21.6_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:22.1_0: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn13:22.2_0: being eaten by crows, or being eaten by hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
ai-mn13:22.3_0: What do you think, mendicants, is beautiful, and appears clearly?”
ai-mn13:22.5_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:23-28.1_0: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn13:23-28.2_0: And she had been reduced to a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews ... a skeleton rid of flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews ... a skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews ...
ai-mn13:23-28.3_0: bones without sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull. ...
ai-mn13:23-28.4_0: What do you think, mendicants, is beautiful, and appears clearly?”
ai-mn13:23-28.6_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:29.1_0: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And she had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
ai-mn13:29.2_0: And she had been reduced to white bones, the color of shells ... decrepit bones, heaped in a pile ... bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
ai-mn13:29.4_0: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
ai-mn13:29.6_0: “This too is the drawback of sights.
ai-mn13:30.1_0: And what is the escape from sights?
ai-mn13:30.2_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sights: this is the escape from sights.
ai-mn13:31.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sights’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sights themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sights.
ai-mn13:31.2_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sights’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sights themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sights.
ai-mn13:32.1_0: And what is the gratification of feelings?
ai-mn13:32.2_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-mn13:32.3_0: At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;
ai-mn13:32.4_0: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.
ai-mn13:32.5_0: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.
ai-mn13:33-35.1_0: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption ...
ai-mn13:33-35.2_0: third time, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare:
ai-mn13:33-35.2_1: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’ ...
ai-mn13:33-35.3_0: fourth absorption. At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;
ai-mn13:33-35.4_0: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.
ai-mn13:33-35.5_0: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.
ai-mn13:36.1_0: And what is the drawback of feelings?
ai-mn13:36.2_0: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
ai-mn13:37.1_0: And what is the escape from feelings?
ai-mn13:37.2_0: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feelings: this is the escape from feelings.
ai-mn13:38.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.
ai-mn13:38.2_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.”
ai-mn13:38.3_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn13:38.4_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn13:38.5_0: The third chapter on the suffering is finished.
